summary: Endometrial cancer is a cancer that arises from the endometrium, the lining of the uterus. It is characterized by abnormal cell growth that can invade or spread to other parts of the body. It is the most common type of uterine cancer and primarily affects women after menopause.
causes: Genetic mutations (e.g., in PTEN, TP53, MLH1, MLH2, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, ARID1A, PIK3CA, KRAS, CTNNB1, FGFR2, SPOP)
risk_factors: Black women (in the US, for Type II)
Trans men on testosterone without hysterectomy
Higher circulating testosterone levels in women
symptoms: Vaginal bleeding not associated with a menstrual period
Vaginal bleeding or spotting after menopause
Extremely long, heavy, or frequent episodes of bleeding (pre-menopause)
Thin white or clear vaginal discharge (postmenopausal women)
diagnosis: Cervical screening test (Pap smear - not typically sufficient)
treatments: Abdominal hysterectomy (total removal of the uterus)
Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (removal of Fallopian tubes and ovaries)
Hormone therapy (progestins, tamoxifen, megestrol acetate, medroxyprogesterone, letrozole, anastrozole)
Targeted therapy (e.g., Dostarlimab, PARP inhibitors like olaparib, mTOR inhibitors like temsirolimus, ridaforolimus, bevacizumab, tyrosine kinase inhibitors, ixabepilone)
Bone marrow or stem cell transplant (not explicitly mentioned for endometrial cancer, but a general cancer treatment)
